reference.title: New Android Virtual Device Instance dialog (startup options)
reference.shortdesc: The third in a sequence of dialogs that are presented when you create a new AVD from the Device Management view, this dialog lets you specify options that are applied when you start the emulator.

section.p: This dialog contains a number of tabs, each with a number of fields. Note that beneath the tabbed sections is a non-editable Startup Arguments field that presents your selected options, command-line style, as they will be passed to the emulator when it is started. See http://d.android.com/guide/developing/tools/emulator.html#startup-options for all of the possible command-line arguments.

strow.stentry: A DPI value that represents a scaling factor to be applied to the emulator window. This allows you to alter the emulator's screen resolution to match the screen size of an actual device. By default, this value is 165. Click the Calculate button to calculate screen resolution and scale values that result in a life-sized image given the screen size of the device being emulated (in inches) and your development computer's display size (in inches) or density (DPI).

A value ranging from 0.1 to 3.0 that represents the scaling factor to be applied to the emulator window. To specify the scale as a DPI value, include a suffix of "dpi". Click the Calculate button to calculate screen resolution and scale values that result in a life-sized image given the screen size of the device being emulated (in inches) and your development computer's display size (in inches) or density (DPI).
Speeds up the emulator startup by disabling the boot animation sequence.

Hides the "skin" that makes the emulated device look more like a specific handheld. Note that the skin includes the device keyboard (if the emulated device has a physical keyboard); hiding the skin makes this keyboard, along with any other physical controls presented by the emulated device, inaccessible. Also note that if you change this option on a running emulator, you will need to stop and restart the emulator for the option to take effect.
The working cache partition image.
The working user-data disk image.
A file containing a user-data disk image that is copied to the working user-data disk image if the Wipe User Data option is selected.
A file that to be used as a RAM-disk image.
An SD card image that will be used by the new AVD instance.
Controls whether or not the AVD uses a cache partition.

Select this option to reset the user-data disk image when the AVD starts up. If a disk image is provided in the Init User Data field, the contents of that file are copied to the working user-data disk image, rather than the emulator's default image.

section.title: Network tab
section.p: The fields on this tab control how the AVD accesses the Internet.

strow.stentry: A comma-separated list of up to four DNS server names or IP addresses to be used by the AVD.
An HTTP/HTTPS proxy through which all TCP connections are routed. See http://d.android.com/guide/developing/tools/emulator.html#startup-options for the format of this field.
Emulates the network latency of various cellular network types, such as GPRS, EDGE, or UMTS.
Throttles the networking speed to simulate that of a cellular network. Use this field to specify the desired network type.
The console port number for this emulator instance. This should be an even integer value that ranges from 5554 to 5584.
Indicates that network operations should proceed at full speed, with no latency.

Allows you to emulate a slow CPU. Supply a value from 0 (no delay) to 1000 (maximum delay). Note that these integer values simply indicate a relative degree of delay and do not represent any actual amount of time.

Emulates an NMEA-compatible GPS device that is connected to an external character device or socket. For information on the format of this field, see the description of the -serial option in the QEMU user documentation, which can be found at http://www.nongnu.org/qemu/qemu-doc.html.
Disables JNI checks in the Dalvik runtime.

Use this field to enter any other startup options not available from the other tabs. Enter the startup options as documented in the Android developer documentation at http://d.android.com/guide/developing/tools/emulator.html#startup-options.
